title: Asos shares jump as fashion firm shrugs off tumbling profits
text:
'Dire' results from Asos have today confirmed that its past financial year is one the online fashion firm will want to forget.

The former stock market darling said profits tumbled 68 per cent in the 12 months to August 31, as it forked out to remedy warehouse issues in Germany and the US, was pipped to the post by rivals on Black Friday and struggled amid weak consumer confidence.

Costly investment and rising costs meant the company even swung into debt, with £95million now on its books.

The former stock market darling said profits tumbled 68% in the 12 months to August 31st

During the torrid year, Asos shares suffered an almighty fall from grace, from highs of around £60 per share last August to just £23 at the start of this month, as investor's feared the firm was falling out of fashion.

However, the stock ticked up by 16 per cent to £29.68 in early trading on Wednesday as Asos attempted to draw a line in the sand.

Investors appear to have been braced for worse numbers than Asos actually delivered, therefore many have seen today as buying opportunity.

Chart shows the sharp decline in Asos's share price in the last year - from highs of around £60

Reassuring bright spots in the results include rising customer numbers and a 13 per cent uplift in sales to £2.73billion as its more 'glam' shoppers snapped up animal print, broderie and satin.

Adam Vettese from eToro said this proves Asos 'it is still incredibly popular with fashion-conscious twenty-somethings'.

But he added: 'The firm will want to see this progress carried into the new year, meaning this is perhaps the most important Christmas trading period in Asos' history.'

The firm's more 'glam' shoppers snapped up animal print, broderie and satin

Boss Nick Beighton hailed an improved performance in the past six months and claimed that the company was ready to enter a new growth phase.

The firm also revealed plans to 'strengthen the depth and breadth' of its senior management team with numerous appointments.

'We have restructured our executive team and over the course of full year 2020 we will be adding new roles including a chief growth officer, chief commercial officer, chief people officer and a chief strategy officer,' the company said.

Other fixes include improving its social media engagement and trying to tap into the next generation of young shoppers.

Interactive Investors' head of markets Richard Hunter said today's numbers are 'fairly dire'.

'The contrast with the full-year numbers this time last year is striking.

'The company had bitten off more than it could chew, and two profit warnings, outages at warehouses in Germany and the US not only revealed a deeper malaise but could even have brought the relevance of the brand into question,' he said.

Hunter added: 'Investors will be hoping that these numbers represent a line in the sand. The initial share price reaction to the results reflect a leap of faith.'

Despite the positive notes and eye on the future, Beighton warned: 'I think there is a very unsettled customer environmental out there. There is an awful lot of global uncertainty for the consumer.'

However, just last month Asos's newer rival Boohoo posted a 43 per cent jump in first-half sales as well as a 53 per cent rise in earnings.

David Madden from CMC Markets said: 'These stellar numbers shows that a well-run online fashion house can thrive in a downbeat climate.'
